title: Introduction to SomaScan.db
text: SomaScan.db package provides extended biological annotations used conjunction results SomaLogic’s SomaScan assay, fee--service proteomic technology platform designed detect proteins across numerous biological pathways. vignette describes use SomaScan.db package annotate SomaScan data, .e. add additional information ADAT file give biological context (gene level) platform’s reagents protein targets. SomaScan.db performs annotation mapping SomaScan reagent IDs (SeqIds) corresponding protein(s) gene(s), well biological pathways (GO, KEGG, etc.) identifiers public data repositories. SomaScan.db utilizes methods setup Bioconductor annotation packages, therefore methods familiar ’ve worked packages previously.

text: list columns returned columns informs us types data available; therefore, column values can used retrieve specific pieces information database. can think keys columns : Keys: information already (SeqIds/probe IDs), aka rows database Columns: data types want retrieve information, aka columns database SomaScan.db database can queried via select, using keys columns. selecting columns keys using select method, keys returned left-column output, PROBEID column. results exact order input keys: Note: message (‘select()’ returned 1:1 mapping keys columns) described detail next section vignette. data returned always order provided keys. select find mapping specific key, NA value returned retain original query order. example , “PROBEID” “ENTREZID” value couldn’t found character string “TEST”, NA returned place.
code: # Randomly select a set of keys example_keys <- withr::with_seed(101L, sample(keys(SomaScan.db),                                               size = 5L,                                               replace = FALSE ))  # Query keys in the database select(SomaScan.db,        keys = example_keys,        columns = c("ENTREZID", "SYMBOL", "GENENAME") ) ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns ##     PROBEID ENTREZID  SYMBOL                                    GENENAME ## 1  20564-53     7070    THY1                  Thy-1 cell surface antigen ## 2   5481-16     5921   RASA1                 RAS p21 protein activator 1 ## 3 17792-158     7915 ALDH5A1   aldehyde dehydrogenase 5 family member A1 ## 4  21760-22     7317    UBA1 ubiquitin like modifier activating enzyme 1 ## 5   5508-62     1509    CTSD                                 cathepsin D # Inserting a new key that won't be found in the annotations ("TEST") test_keys <- c(example_keys[1], "TEST")  select(SomaScan.db, keys = test_keys, columns = c("PROBEID", "ENTREZID")) ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns ##    PROBEID ENTREZID ## 1 20564-53     7070 ## 2     <NA>     <NA>

title: Advanced Exploration of the SomaScan Menu
text: Similar extended GO annotation previous section, positional annotation currently performed within SomaScan.db. SomaScan.db platform-centric annotation package, built around probes SomaScan protein assay, positional annotation within scope. However, possible retrieve positional annotations linking Bioconductor annotation resources, can combined SomaScan.db two-step process (similar ). first step uses SomaScan.db retrieve gene-level information corresponding SomaScan analytes; second requires human transcriptome organism-centric annotation package retrieve desired chromosomal locations. provide brief example using popular organism-centric package, EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75, contains database human annotations derived Ensembl release 75. However, procedure can also performed using transcriptome-centric annotation packages like TxDb.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg19.knownGene. Let’s say interested collecting position information associated protein target corresponding SeqId = 11138-16. First, must determine gene SeqId maps : now know probe targets protein encoded RUNX3 gene. can use EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75 retrieve positional information RUNX3, like chromosome RUNX3 , start stop position, many exons (time Ensembl’s v75 release):
code: pos_sel <- select(SomaScan.db, "11138-16", columns = c("SYMBOL", "GENENAME",                                                         "ENTREZID", "ENSEMBL")) ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns pos_sel ##    PROBEID SYMBOL                           GENENAME ENTREZID ## 1 11138-16  RUNX3 RUNX family transcription factor 3      864 ##           ENSEMBL ## 1 ENSG00000020633 # Install package from Bioconductor, if not already installed if (!require("EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75", quietly = TRUE)) {     BiocManager::install("EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75") }  # The central keys of the organism-level database are the Ensembl gene ID keys(EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75)[1:10L]  # Also contains the Ensembl gene ID, so this column can be used for merging grep("ENSEMBL", columns(SomaScan.db), value = TRUE)  # These columns will inform us as to what positional information we can  # retrieve from the organism-level database columns(EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75)  # Build a query to retrieve the prot IDs and start/stop pos of protein domains pos_res <- select(EnsDb.Hsapiens.v75, keys = "ENSG00000020633",                    columns = c("GENEBIOTYPE", "SEQCOORDSYSTEM", "GENEID",                                "PROTEINID", "PROTDOMSTART", "PROTDOMEND"))  # Merge back into `pos_sel` using the "GENEID" column merge(pos_sel, pos_res, by.x = "ENSEMBL", by.y = "GENEID")

title: Advanced Exploration of the SomaScan Menu
text: annotations SomaScan.db can used answer general questions SomaScan, without need SomaScan dataset/ADAT file starting point. example, one interested proteins involved cancer progression metastasis (therefore cell adhesion), SomaScan menu capable measuring proteins involved cell adhesion? , many proteins can measured SomaScan? can answer examining coverage GO term “cell adhesion” 5k 7k SomaScan menus. don’t need GO identifier get started, information can retrieved GO.db using name term key: Now GO ID, can search SomaScan.db determine many SeqIds associated cell adhesion. 377 unique SeqIds associated “cell adhesion” GO term (unique important data frame may contain multiple entries per SeqId, due “EVIDENCE” column). 7267 total SeqIds SomaScan.db database, 5.19% keys database associated cell adhesion. many total proteins cell adhesion GO term covered SomaScan menu? answer question, first must use another annotation package, org.Hs.eg.db, retrieve list human UniProt IDs associated “cell adhesion” GO term. GO term GO:0007155 (cell adhesion) contains total 875 unique human UniProt IDs. Now can check see many covered SomaScan menu searching proteins SomaScan.db select: select return NA value key found database. seen , proteins GO:0007155 map SeqId SomaScan.db. get accurate count proteins map SeqId, must remove unmapped proteins filtering rows NA values: removed duplicates list proteins provided keys, get final count 542 proteins (61.94%) “cell adhesion” GO term covered SomaScan menu. number differ versions SomaScan Menu? Remember 7k menu contains SeqIds 5k menu, really tells us : analytes targeting cell adhesion-related proteins added 7k menu? example, number SeqIds associated cell adhesion differ SomaScan menu versions (list SeqIds identical). differences menu versions can explored menu argument select, via somascan_menu data object (explained Introductory Vignette).
code: select(GO.db, keys = "cell adhesion", keytype = "TERM",         columns = c("GOID", "TERM")) ## 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns ##            TERM       GOID ## 1 cell adhesion GO:0007155 cellAd_ids <- select(SomaScan.db, keys = "GO:0007155", keytype = "GO",                      columns = "PROBEID", "UNIPROTID") ## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns head(cellAd_ids, n = 10L) ##            GO   PROBEID EVIDENCE ONTOLOGY ## 1  GO:0007155  10037-98      IBA       BP ## 2  GO:0007155  10511-10      IEA       BP ## 3  GO:0007155  10521-10      IEA       BP ## 4  GO:0007155  10539-30      IEA       BP ## 5  GO:0007155  10558-26      IBA       BP ## 6  GO:0007155   10702-1      IBA       BP ## 7  GO:0007155 10748-216      IBA       BP ## 8  GO:0007155 10907-116      IEA       BP ## 9  GO:0007155  10980-11      IDA       BP ## 10 GO:0007155  11067-13      NAS       BP # Total number of SeqIds associated with cell adhesion unique(cellAd_ids$PROBEID) |> length() ## [1] 377 cellAd_prots <- select(org.Hs.eg.db,                         keys = "GO:0007155",                         keytype = "GO",                         columns = "UNIPROT") ## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns # Again, we take the unique set of proteins length(unique(cellAd_prots$UNIPROT)) ## [1] 875 cellAd_covProts <- select(SomaScan.db, keys = unique(cellAd_prots$UNIPROT),                           keytype = "UNIPROT", columns = "PROBEID") ## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns head(cellAd_covProts, n = 20L) ##       UNIPROT  PROBEID ## 1      P42684  3342-76 ## 2      P42684  5261-13 ## 3      P22303 10980-11 ## 4      P22303 15553-22 ## 5      P35609 9844-138 ## 6  A0A0S2Z381 19751-21 ## 7      P00813 19751-21 ## 8      F5GWI4 19751-21 ## 9      E7ENV9  3280-49 ## 10     E7EX88  3280-49 ## 11 A0A1U9X785  4125-52 ## 12     B4DNX3  4125-52 ## 13     Q15109  4125-52 ## 14     Q13740   5451-1 ## 15     B3KNN9   5451-1 ## 16     Q546D7     <NA> ## 17     Q9NP70     <NA> ## 18     P02760  15453-3 ## 19     Q99217     <NA> ## 20     Q02410     <NA> cellAd_covProts <- cellAd_covProts[!is.na(cellAd_covProts$PROBEID),]  cellAd_covIDs <- unique(cellAd_covProts$UNIPROT)  length(cellAd_covIDs) ## [1] 542 cellAd_menu <- lapply(c("5k", "7k"), function(x) {     df <- select(SomaScan.db, keys = unique(cellAd_prots$UNIPROT),                  keytype = "UNIPROT", columns = "PROBEID",                  menu = x)          # Again, removing probes that do not map to a cell adhesion protein     df <- df[!is.na(df$PROBEID),] }) |> setNames(c("somascan_5k", "somascan_7k")) ## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns ## 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns identical(cellAd_menu$somascan_5k, cellAd_menu$somascan_7k) ## [1] TRUE

title: Advanced Exploration of the SomaScan Menu
text: number gene families targeted reagents SomaScan assay. can interrogated using SomaScan.db? package capable searching /within specific gene families? answer yes, specific function exist analyzing gene families whole. Instead, using features select keys, SomaScan.db can queried common features connecting gene families interest - specifically, match= argument select pattern= argument keys can used retrieve gene family members contain common pattern name. keys method capable using regular expressions (“regex”) search keys database contain specific pattern characters. feature especially useful looking annotations gene family. example, regex pattern can used retrieve list IL17 receptor family genes database: keys can used query database select: multiple gene families interest, keys argument select (combination match=TRUE) can support regex pattern, accomplish previous steps single call: GENENAME column can also support regex pattern, can used search keywords associated specific gene families (just gene symbols ). Examples include “homeobox”, “zinc finger”, “notch”, etc.

title: Example ADAT Workflow Using SomaScan.db
text: vignette illustrate SomaScan.db package can used extend results basic bioinformatic analyses performed SomaScan data. vignette, use tools SomaDataIO, conjunction SomaScan.db, identify annotate proteins (ultimately, genes biological pathways) associated clinical variable interest; e.g. Age. workflow assumes user basic knowledge R programming language. addition, assumed user familiar ADAT format, well documentation SomaDataIO SomaLogic-Data Github repository. information ADAT format, well detailed description fields found ADAT, please reference SomaLogic-Data repository README.
code: library(dplyr) library(GO.db) library(SomaDataIO) library(SomaScan.db)

title: Example ADAT Workflow Using SomaScan.db
text: ADAT file format SomaLogic-specific, tab-delimited text file designed store SomaScan study data. example ADAT file used walkthrough, example_data10.adat, contains SomaScan 5k study set 10 human samples. measurements identifiers altered protect personally identifiable information (PII), retaining underlying biological signal much possible. begin, utilize SomaDataIO::read_adat() load example ADAT file:
code: # Retrieve the example ADAT file from the SomaDataIO package file <- system.file("extdata", "example_data10.adat",                     package = "SomaDataIO", mustWork = TRUE ) # Read in the file adat <- SomaDataIO::read_adat(file)  adat ## ══ SomaScan Data ═════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ ##      Attributes intact    ✓ ##      Rows                 10 ##      Columns              5318 ##      Clinical Data        34 ## ℹ Dilution, PlateScale_Reference, CalReference, ## ℹ Cal_Example_Adat_Set001, ColCheck, ## ℹ CalQcRatio_Example_Adat_Set001_170255, QcReference_170255, ## ℹ Cal_Example_Adat_Set002, CalQcRatio_Example_Adat_Set002_170255, ## title: Example ADAT Workflow Using SomaScan.db
text: can now examine data see analytes correlated variable Age. First, however, data pre-processed. SomaLogic generally recommends log-transform RFU values ADAT prior analysis. log-transformation, can examine correlations identify analytes positively correlated Age. , correlations calculated using stats::cor.test(): table contains analytes strong positive correlation Age, information alone may enough derive meaningful biological insights. proteins genes identifiers correspond ? correlated proteins functionally related way, perhaps part biological pathway? types questions SomaScan.db designed address. next section, annotate data querying SeqIds SomaScan.db retrieve additional information corresponding genes gene types.
code: log10_adat <- log10(adat) # Calculate correlations for each analyte cors_df <- lapply(analytes, function(x) {     results <- stats::cor.test(log10_adat$Age, log10_adat[[x]],                                method = "spearman", exact = FALSE)     results <- results[c("estimate", "p.value")]     unlist(results) }) %>% setNames(analytes)  # Bind results together into a single dataframe cors_df <- dplyr::bind_rows(cors_df, .id = "analytes")  # Isolate top positive correlations top_posCor <- cors_df %>%     dplyr::filter(p.value < 0.05) %>% # Retain significant cors only     dplyr::filter(estimate.rho >= 0.75) %>% # Retain strong correlations     arrange(desc(estimate.rho))  nrow(top_posCor) ## [1] 98 head(top_posCor, 20L) ## # A tibble: 20 × 3 ##    analytes     estimate.rho   p.value ##    <chr>               <dbl>     <dbl> ##  1 seq.7655.11         0.95  0.0000876 ##  2 seq.9942.2          0.95  0.0000876 ##  3 seq.15326.64        0.933 0.000236  ##  4 seq.6444.15         0.933 0.000236  ##  5 seq.3362.61         0.917 0.000507  ##  6 seq.12988.49        0.9   0.000943  ##  7 seq.15640.54        0.9   0.000943  ##  8 seq.16890.37        0.9   0.000943  ##  9 seq.9266.1          0.9   0.000943  ## 10 seq.16785.45        0.883 0.00159   ## 11 seq.3336.50         0.883 0.00159   ## 12 seq.4666.199        0.883 0.00159   ## 13 seq.8304.50         0.883 0.00159   ## 14 seq.2944.66         0.867 0.00250   ## 15 seq.3434.34         0.867 0.00250   ## 16 seq.3435.53         0.867 0.00250   ## 17 seq.3440.7          0.867 0.00250   ## 18 seq.4131.72         0.867 0.00250   ## 19 seq.4907.56         0.867 0.00250   ## 20 seq.4914.10         0.867 0.00250

title: Somalogic SomaScan Annotation Data
text: SomaScan.db package platform-centric R package provides extended biological annotations analytes SomaScan assay menu, using resources provided Bioconductor project. package exposes database object, SomaScan.db, SQLite database can queried retrieve annotations SomaScan analytes. SomaScan.db structured around primary identifier, SomaLogic sequence ID (SeqId). Please note cases, identifier may also referred “PROBEID”. SeqIds cornerstone SomaScan assay, used uniquely identify SomaLogic analytes. SomaScan.db package enables mapping SeqIds identifiers popular public data repositories, many gene-based, vice versa. information SeqIds, please see ?SomaDataIO::SeqId.

title: Somalogic SomaScan Annotation Data
text: SomaScan.db can installed recent Bioconductor release using BiocManager package: development version SomaScan.db, containing current features /updates, can installed GitHub: installed, package can loaded using usual syntax:
code: # If not already installed, install BiocManager if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE)) {     install.packages("BiocManager") }  BiocManager::install("SomaScan.db") remotes::install_github("SomaLogic/SomaScan.db") library(SomaScan.db)

title: Somalogic SomaScan Annotation Data
text: SomaScan.db package requires R >= 4.3.0, depends following R packages: comes bundled R installation install Bioconductor: BiocManager::install("AnnotationDbi") may also want install another SomaLogic’s R packages, SomaDataIO, designed reading, writing, manipulating ADATs. already used SomaDataIO work SomaScan data, likely find highly useful. SomaDataIO available CRAN.

title: Somalogic SomaScan Annotation Data
text: annotations SomaScan.db can queried using 5 methods common amongst Bioconductor annotation packages: keys returns list central identifiers package, aka SomaScan analytes, annotations available: keytypes lists data types can used keys query SQLite database: columns lists available data types: mapIds retrieves annotation data (single data type, aka column): select retrieves annotation data en masse (multiple columns) using values keys columns: select can also used identify SeqIds associated gene protein interest (, PROBEID refers SomaScan SeqIds): detailed usage examples, please see SomaScan.db package vignettes, introductory vignette Bioconductor’s AnnotationDbi:
code: keys(SomaScan.db) keytypes(SomaScan.db) columns(SomaScan.db) mapIds(SomaScan.db, keys = "18342-2", columns = "SYMBOL", multiVals = "first") select(SomaScan.db, keys = "18342-2", columns = c("SYMBOL", "UNIPROT")) select(SomaScan.db, keys = "EGFR", keytype = "SYMBOL", columns = "PROBEID") vignette("IntroToAnnotationPackages", package = "AnnotationDbi")

text: list containing following elements: v4.1_analytes character vector SomaScan analytes. V4.0 vector contains 4,966 elements SeqId format (e.g. 1234-56). v4.0_analytes character vector SomaScan analytes. V4.1 vector contains 7,267 elements SeqId format (e.g. 1234-56).

title: SomaScan Menu Character Vectors — DataObjects
text: https://github.com/SomaLogic/SomaLogic-Data SomaLogic Operating Co., Inc.

title: SomaScan Menu Character Vectors — DataObjects
text: somascan_menu object list character vectors analytes available SomaScan menu. currently available vectors somascan_menu object correspond V4.0 ("5k") V4.1 ("7k") menus, named accordingly. Older menus (ex. V4.0 menu) contain fewer analytes recent releases (ex. V4.1 menu), subsequent release introduces new analytes targeting additional proteins. Consequently, V4.1 menu contains analytes present V4.0 menu, V4.0 menu contain analytes V4.1.

title: Map between SomaScan SeqIds and Gene Ontology (GO) identifiers — SomaScanGO
text: SomaScanGO cast list, SeqId     mapped list lists. names outer list GO     identifiers. inner list consists three named elements:      GOID, Ontology, Evidence. GOID element matches GO identifier named outer      list included convenience processing data using      lapply(). Ontology element indicates three Gene Ontology     categories identifier belongs . categories biological     process (BP), cellular component (CC), molecular function (MF). Evidence element contains code indicating kind      evidence supports association GO identifier SeqId.     evidence codes use include:  IMP: inferred mutant phenotype IGI: inferred genetic interaction IPI: inferred physical interaction ISS: inferred sequence similarity IDA: inferred direct assay IEP: inferred expression pattern IEA: inferred electronic annotation TAS: traceable author statement NAS: non-traceable author statement ND: biological data available IC: inferred curator complete listing evidence codes can found     http://www.geneontology.org/GO.evidence.shtml SomaScanGO2ALLPROBES SomaScanGO2PROBE cast      list, GO term maps named vector SeqIds     evidence codes. GO identifier may mapped manufacturer     identifier evidence code can     different. Mappings Gene Ontology identifiers, Gene     Ontology terms, information available separate data     package named GO. Whenever mappings cast data.frame,     results output appropriate tabular form. Mappings SeqIds GO information     obtained mappings SeqIds. NA valuess     assigned SeqIds mapped Gene     Ontology information. mappings based data provided Gene Ontology      (http://current.geneontology.org/ontology/go-basic.obo),      date stamp source : 2021-09-01

code: ## select() interface: ## Objects in this package can be accessed using the select() interface ## from the AnnotationDbi package. See ?select for details.  ## Bimap interface: x <- SomaScanGO # Get the manufacturer identifiers that are mapped to a GO ID mapped_genes <- mappedkeys(x) # Convert to a list xx <- as.list(x[mapped_genes][1:300]) if(length(xx) > 0) {     # Try the first one     got <- xx[[1]]                got[[1]][["GOID"]]     got[[1]][["Ontology"]]     got[[1]][["Evidence"]] } #> [1] "IBA" # For the reverse map: x <- SomaScanGO2PROBE mapped_genes <- mappedkeys(x) # Convert to a list xx <- as.list(x[mapped_genes][1:300]) if(length(xx) > 0){     # Gets the manufacturer ids for the top 2nd and 3nd GO identifiers     goids <- xx[2:3]     # Gets the manufacturer ids for the first element of goids     goids[[1]]     # Evidence code for the mappings     names(goids[[1]]) } #>  [1] "IBA" "IBA" "IEA" "IEA" "IMP" "IMP" "IEA" "IEA" "IBA" "IMP" "IEA" #> [12] "IBA" "IEA" "TAS" "IMP" "IEA" "TAS" "IEA" "IEA" "IMP" "IEA" "IEA" #> [23] "IBA" "IBA" "IMP" "IEA" "IMP" "IBA" "IDA" "TAS" "IEA" "IEA" "TAS" #> [34] "TAS" "TAS" "IMP" "TAS" "IEA" "IEA" "TAS" "IBA" "IEA" "IBA" "TAS" #> [45] "IBA" "TAS" "IEA" "IBA" "NAS" "IEA" "TAS" "IBA" "ISS" "TAS" "IEA" #> [56] "IEA" "TAS" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IMP" "TAS" "IMP" "IEA" #> [67] "TAS" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "TAS"  x <- SomaScanGO2ALLPROBES mapped_genes <- mappedkeys(x) # Convert SomaScanGO2ALLPROBES to a list xx <- as.list(x[mapped_genes][1:300]) if(length(xx) > 0){ # Gets the manufacturer identifiers for the top 2nd and 3nd GO identifiers     goids <- xx[2:3]     # Gets all the manufacturer identifiers for the first element of goids     goids[[1]]     # Evidence code for the mappings     names(goids[[1]]) } #>  [1] "IBA" "IEA" "IEA" "IBA" "ISS" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "ISS" "IEA" #> [12] "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "IBA" "IBA" "IBA" "IEA" "IEA" #> [23] "ISS" "IEA" "ISS" "IEA" "IBA" "IBA" "IEA" "IBA" "IDA" "IEA" "ISS" #> [34] "IEA" "ISS" "ISS" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" "ISS" "ISS" "IEA" "IEA" "IEA" #> [45] "IEA" "IEA"

title: Maps between SomaScan SeqIds and PubMed identifiers — SomaScanPMID
code: ## select() interface: ## Objects in this package can be accessed using the select() interface ## from the AnnotationDbi package. See ?select for details.  ## Bimap interface: x <- SomaScanPMID # Get the probe identifiers that are mapped to any PubMed ID mapped_probes <- mappedkeys(x) # Convert to a list xx <- as.list(x[mapped_probes][1:300]) if(length(xx) > 0){     # Get the PubMed identifiers for the first two probe identifiers     xx[1:2]     # Get the first one     xx[[1]]     if(interactive() && !is.null(xx[[1]]) && !is.na(xx[[1]])      && require(annotate)){         # Get article information as XML files         xmls <- pubmed(xx[[1]], disp = "data")         # View article information using a browser         pubmed(xx[[1]], disp = "browser")     } }  x <- SomaScanPMID2PROBE mapped_probes <- mappedkeys(x) # Now convert the reverse map object SomaScanPMID2PROBE to a list xx <- as.list(x[mapped_probes][1:300]) if(length(xx) > 0){     # Get the probe identifiers for the first two PubMed identifiers     xx[1:2]     # Get the first one     xx[[1]]     if(interactive() && require(annotate)){         # Get article information as XML files for a PubMed id         xmls <- pubmed(names(xx)[1], disp = "data")         # View article information using a browser         pubmed(names(xx)[1], disp = "browser")     } }

title: Map between SomaScan SeqIds and Gene Symbols — SomaScanSYMBOL
code: ## select() interface: ## Objects in this package can be accessed using the select() interface ## from the AnnotationDbi package. See ?select for details.  ## Bimap interface: x <- SomaScanSYMBOL # Get the probe identifiers that are mapped to a gene symbol mapped_probes <- mappedkeys(x) # Convert to a list xx <- as.list(x[mapped_probes][1:300]) if(length(xx) > 0) {     # Get the SYMBOL for the first five probes     xx[1:5]     # Get the first value     xx[[1]] } #> [1] "CRYBB2"

title: Map between SomaScan SeqIds and the full name of the protein target — SomaTARGETFULLNAME
text: manufacturer identifier mapped full name SOMAmer      protein target. NA reported target name      information given SOMAmer reagent. full protein target name typically written sentence case without     using gene symbol abbreviations, however gene symbols can still      occasionally found target names. information can also      found ADAT file accompanying target name (abbreviated      version full name found mapping). Mappings based data provided : SomaLogic     (https://somalogic.com/somascan-menu/),      date stamp source : 2023-Oct

what: Add Target Full Name information to data frame — addTargetFullName
title: Add Target Full Name information to data frame — addTargetFullName
text: Retrieve Target Full Name given SeqId (set SeqIds) add information data frame. Target Full Name can found ADAT file represents full name protein target primary SOMAmer reagent. Note: can retrieve list Target Full Name values given set SeqIds mget(seqids, SomaScanTARGETFULLNAME), seqids character vector SeqIds. retrieve data frame Target Full Name values present package, use toTable(SomaScanTARGETFULLNAME).

what: The keytypes method for SomaDb objects — keytypes,SomaDb-method
title: The keytypes method for SomaDb objects — keytypes,SomaDb-method
text: keytypes produces vector annotation categories can used input keys keytype= argument select, mapIds, keys methods. keytype also informs query format search key. example, searching database annotations corresponding gene "NOTCH3", key "NOTCH3" keytype "SYMBOL". Specifying keytype="SYMBOL" ensures gene symbol confused different identifier ("key") type. default keytype ("PROBEID"), corresponds SomaLogic SeqId. information database keys, see ?keys.

what: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
text: mapIds retrieve SomaScan annotations (named vector) based parameters provided keys, columns, keytype arguments. default keytype "PROBEID", e.g. SomaLogic SeqId; value used tie annotations back SomaScan-specific identifier.

title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
code: # S4 method for SomaDb mapIds(   x,   keys,   column,   keytype,   menu = NULL,   match = FALSE,   ...,   multiVals = c("filter", "asNA", "first", "list", "CharacterList") )

title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
text: x AnnotationDb object. practice mean      object derived AnnotationDb object OrgDb      ChipDb object. keys keys select records database.  possible      keys returned using keys method. column column search (mapIds).  Different      columns can single element value keytype keytype matches keys used.      select methods, used indicate kind ID used     keys argument. keys method used     indicate kind keys desired keys menu character string identifying SomaScan menu version (optional). filter keys specified menu return data associated analytes present menu. default, annotations analytes available. Options include either "5k" "7k", well version numbers menus, "v4.0" "v4.1" (respectively). match logical (TRUE/FALSE). Must used "SYMBOL", "ALIAS", "GENENAME" keytypes . true, character string provided keys used search term. string used match symbols also start string (ex. key "CASP1" return annotations CASP10 & CASP14 genes). ... Arguments passed AnnotationDbi::mapIds   multiVals mapIds multiple values            returned?  Options include: first: value means multiple matches 1st thing comes back returned. default behavior list: just returns list object end user filter: remove elements contain multiple matches therefore return shorter vector came whenever keys match one value asNA: return NA value whenever multiple matches CharacterList: just returns SimpleCharacterList object FUN: can also supply function multiVals argument custom behaviors.  function must take single argument return single value.  function applied elements serve 'rule' thing keep one element.  example example function always grab last element result:  last <- function(x){x[[length(x)]]}

title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
text: named character vector containing retrieved annotations. Missing values returned NA.

title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
text: mapIds similar select can used retrieve annotation information database. However, users aware call mapIds request columns multiple matches specified keys (ex. GO pathway-related terms), mapIds return named character vector (default) one result possible match. result results truncated. Make sure specify appropriate multiVals parameter query.

title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
text: Amanda Hiser

title: The mapIds method for SomaDb objects — mapIds,SomaDb-method
code: # Retrieve a set of example keys keys <- head(keys(SomaScan.db)) keys #> [1] "10000-28" "10001-7"  "10003-15" "10006-25" "10008-43" "10010-10"  # Only 1 result is returned by default; missing values are returned as `NA` mapIds(SomaScan.db, keys = keys, column = "UNIPROT") #> 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns #>     10000-28      10001-7     10003-15     10006-25     10008-43  #>     "P43320"     "L7RRS6"     "P51814" "A0A024R1A7"           NA  #>     10010-10  #> "A0A024R1X5"   # Specify `multiVals` to return all results as a list mapIds(SomaScan.db, keys = keys, column = "UNIPROT", multiVals = "list") #> 'select()' returned 1:many mapping between keys and columns #> $`10000-28` #> [1] "P43320" "R4UMM2" #>  #> $`10001-7` #> [1] "L7RRS6"     "P04049"     "A0A0S2Z4L5" #>  #> $`10003-15` #> [1] "P51814"     "A0A024R1C4" #>  #> $`10006-25` #> [1] "A0A024R1A7" "P19419"     "Q86SR6"     #>  #> $`10008-43` #> [1] NA #>  #> $`10010-10` #> [1] "A0A024R1X5" "Q14457"     "W0FFG4"     "B4DQ36"     "E7EV84"     #>

title: The select method for SomaDb objects — select,SomaDb-method
code: # Retrieve a set of example keys keys <- head(keys(SomaScan.db)) keys #> [1] "10000-28" "10001-7"  "10003-15" "10006-25" "10008-43" "10010-10"  # Look up the gene symbol and gene type for all example keys select(SomaScan.db, keys = keys, columns = c("SYMBOL", "GENETYPE")) #> 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns #>    PROBEID SYMBOL       GENETYPE #> 1 10000-28 CRYBB2 protein-coding #> 2  10001-7   RAF1 protein-coding #> 3 10003-15  ZNF41 protein-coding #> 4 10006-25   ELK1 protein-coding #> 5 10008-43 GUCA1A protein-coding #> 6 10010-10  BECN1 protein-coding  # Look up SomaScan SeqIds associated with a gene of interest select(SomaScan.db, keys = "NOTCH3", keytype = "SYMBOL",        columns = c("PROBEID", "UNIPROT")) #> 'select()' returned 1:1 mapping between keys and columns #>   SYMBOL PROBEID UNIPROT #> 1 NOTCH3 5108-72  Q9UM47
